required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pediatric ACTION3 (Identify, Treat, Control): Effectiveness of Adding Montelukast in Pediatric Subjects With Uncontrolled Asthma (0476-385)
clinical_study.official_title: A 12 Week Multicenter, Open-label, Observational Study to Evaluate the Effectiveness of Montelukast Sodium (Singulair®), 4 or 5 mg/Day in Pediatric Subjects With Uncontrolled Asthma

brief_summary.textblock: a study to describe patient and physician satisfaction with montelukast therapy for the control of asthma used either as monotherapy or in combination with inhaled corticosteroids

primary_outcome.description: ACQ is a questionnaire consisting of seven 7-point Likert scale questions describing frequency and severity of asthma symptoms. Score ranges between 0 (well-controlled) and 6 (extremely poorly controlled); a score of ≤0.75 indicates well controlled symptoms.

secondary_outcome.description: ACQ is a questionnaire consisting of seven 7-point Likert scale questions describing frequency and severity of asthma symptoms. Score ranges between 0 (well-controlled) and 6 (extremely poorly controlled); a score of ≤0.75 indicates well controlled symptoms.

other_outcome.description: At week 0, 4, 8 and 12, physicians were asked to complete a single question describing how satisfied they were regarding the asthma controller medication for each of their enrolled patients.
At week 0, 4, 8 and 12, patients were asked to complete a single question describing how satisfied they were regarding their asthma controller medication.

other_outcome.measure: Pediatric Asthma Caregiver's Quality of Life Questionnaire (PACQLQ)
other_outcome.description: The change in the quality of life of the caregivers of patients treated with montelukast for the control of asthma used in combination with inhaled corticosteroids, using the Pediatric Asthma Caregiver's Quality of Life Questionnaire (PACQLQ). PACQLQ score ranges between 1 (severe impairment) and 7 (no impairment) where a higher score indicates better quality of life. An average change in overall score ≥0.7 is considered clinically significant. Changes between visits and baseline are described.

intervention.description: Montelukast 4-5 mg for 12 weeks, oral tablet

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient Is Diagnosed With Asthma For At Least 6 Months
- Patient's Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF) Is 80% Of Predicted Value (Appendix 10)
- Patient Is Currently Untreated, Or Patient Is A User Of Short-Acting 2-Agonist On An As-Needed Basis, Or Patient Is A User Of Ics At Any Dosage
- Physician And/Or Patient Are Dissatisfied With Current Controller Therapy, Or Patient Is Reluctant To Take Ics Therapy, Or Patient Is Insufficiently Controlled Due To Non-Adherence With Current Therapy Through The Preceding 6 Weeks
Exclusion Criteria:
- As Per Canadian Guidelines, Patient Is On A Laba Alone (Formoterol (Oxeze), Salmeterol (Serevent)) Or A Combination Product (Advair Or Symbicort)
- Patient Is Well Controlled, Adherent And Satisfied With Current Controller Therapy

link.description: MedWatch - FDA maintained medical product safety Information
Merck: Patient & Caregiver U.S. Product Web Site

results_reference.citation: Bérubé D, Djandji M, Sampalis JS, Becker A. Effectiveness of montelukast administered as monotherapy or in combination with inhaled corticosteroid in pediatric patients with uncontrolled asthma: a prospective cohort study. Allergy Asthma Clin Immunol. 2014 May 6;10(1):21. doi: 10.1186/1710-1492-10-21. eCollection 2014.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: First patient in: JUN-19-2006 Last patient out: OCT-28-2008 Total number of sites: 37 sites in Canada

group.description: Montelukast 4-5 mg for 12 weeks, oral tablet

participants_list.participants: 445 – number of patients that signed the informed consent form (Safety population)
420 –patients that received at least one dose of study medication and had 1 follow-up visit (ITT)

group.title: Montelukast

outcome.title: Asthma Control Questionnaire (ACQ)
outcome.description: ACQ is a questionnaire consisting of seven 7-point Likert scale questions describing frequency and severity of asthma symptoms. Score ranges between 0 (well-controlled) and 6 (extremely poorly controlled); a score of ≤0.75 indicates well controlled symptoms.
outcome.population: 420 patients qualified for inclusion in the intent to treat (ITT) analysis and completed the first visit. The following results are based on the 411 patients who completed week 4 and the 373 patients who completed week 12.

class.title: Not tapered and Not well controlled

outcome.title: Physician Global Satisfaction
outcome.description: At week 0, 4, 8 and 12, physicians were asked to complete a single question describing how satisfied they were regarding the asthma controller medication for each of their enrolled patients.
outcome.population: 420 patients qualified for inclusion in the intent to treat (ITT) analysis and completed the first visit. The following results are based on the 411 patients who completed week 4, the 247 who completed week 8, and the 373 patients who completed week 12.

measure.title: Physician Global Satisfaction
measure.description: At week 0, 4, 8 and 12, physicians were asked to complete a single question describing how satisfied they were regarding the asthma controller medication for each of their enrolled patients.
measure.population: 420 patients qualified for inclusion in the intent to treat (ITT) analysis and completed the first visit. The following results are based on the 411 patients who completed week 4, the 247 who completed week 8, and the 373 patients who completed week 12.

analysis.method_desc: The McNemar-Bowker test is a statistical procedure used to compare the proportion of physician satisfaction at week 0 compared to week 12.
The McNemar-Bowker test is a statistical procedure used to compare the proportion of physician satisfaction at week 0 compared to week 8.

outcome.title: Pediatric Asthma Caregiver’s Quality of Life Questionnaire (PACQLQ)
outcome.description: The change in the quality of life of the caregivers of patients treated with montelukast for the control of asthma used in combination with inhaled corticosteroids, using the Pediatric Asthma Caregiver’s Quality of Life Questionnaire (PACQLQ). PACQLQ score ranges between 1 (severe impairment) and 7 (no impairment) where a higher score indicates better quality of life. An average change in overall score ≥0.7 is considered clinically significant. Changes between visits and baseline are described.
outcome.population: 420 patients qualified for inclusion in the intent to treat (ITT) analysis and completed the first visit. The following results are based on the 411 patients who completed week 4, the 247 who completed week 8, and the 373 patients who completed week 12.

PACQLQ score ranges between 1 (severe impairment) and 7 (no impairment) where a higher score indicates better quality of life. An average change in overall score ≥0.7 is considered clinically significant. Changes between visits and baseline are described.
measure.population: 420 patients qualified for inclusion in the intent to treat (ITT) analysis and completed the first visit. The following results are based on the 411 patients who completed week 4, the 247 who completed week 8, and the 373 patients who completed week 12.

analysis.method_desc: Change in PACQLQ score between Week 12 and baseline is statistically different than zero

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Merck agreements may vary with individual investigators, but will not prohibit any investigator from publishing. Merck supports the publication of results from all centers of a multi-center trial but requests that reports based on single-site data not precede the primary publication of the entire clinical trial.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Senior Vice President, Global Clinical Development
